sour.description: A sharp, acidic, lemony taste is a classic sign of under-extraction. The water hasn't had enough time or energy to dissolve the sweeter, more complex flavor compounds.

grind_coarse.question: Does your coffee grinds look too much like coarse sand or breadcrumbs?
grind_coarse.solution: Try adjusting your grinder to a finer setting. This increases the surface area of the coffee, allowing for more efficient extraction.

water_temp_low.question: Is your water temperature below 90°C (195°F)?
water_temp_low.solution: Increase your water temperature. The ideal range for most brewing methods is 92-96°C (198-205°F).

brew_time_short.question: Did your brew finish much faster than the recipe suggested?
brew_time_short.solution: Extend the contact time between the water and coffee. For pour-overs, pour the water more slowly. For immersion brewers, increase the steep time.

coffee_water_ratio_off.question: Is your water temperature below 90°C (195°F)?
coffee_water_ratio_off.solution: Increase your water temperature. Hotter water has more energy to extract flavors. Aim for the 92-96°C (198-205°F) range for most brewing methods.

bitter.description: A harsh, burnt, or unpleasantly astringent aftertaste is the primary indicator of over-extraction. The water has dissolved too many compounds from the coffee, including the bitter ones.

grind_fine.question: Do your coffee grounds look powdery, like flour or fine table salt?
grind_fine.solution: Adjust your grinder to a coarser setting. This will reduce the surface area and slow down the extraction process.

water_temp_high.question: Is your water boiling or very close to boiling (above 96°C or 205°F)?
water_temp_high.solution: Let your water cool for 30-60 seconds after it boils. Using water that is too hot can scorch the grounds and extract bitter flavors.

brew_time_long.question: Did your brew take significantly longer than the recipe's target time?
brew_time_long.solution: Shorten the contact time. For pour-overs, pour faster or grind coarser. For immersion brewers, reduce your steep time.

weak.description: A thin, watery, or tea-like taste that lacks body and flavor intensity. This usually means the ratio of coffee to water is too low.

insufficient_coffee.question: Are you following a standard coffee-to-water ratio (e.g., 1:15 to 1:17)?
insufficient_coffee.solution: Increase your dose of coffee for the same amount of water. A good starting point is to add 1-2 more grams of coffee.

channeling.question: When brewing a pour-over, did you notice water seeming to rush through certain spots in the coffee bed?
channeling.solution: Focus on creating a flat, level bed of coffee before brewing. Pour the water gently and evenly over the entire surface to ensure uniform extraction.

grind_too_coarse.question: Is your grind size very coarse, preventing proper extraction within the brew time?
grind_too_coarse.solution: Even if your primary taste is 'weak' and not 'sour', a grind that is too coarse can prevent enough flavor from being extracted. Try a slightly finer grind.

hollow.description: The coffee has some initial flavor, perhaps some sweetness or acidity, but it lacks depth and the taste disappears quickly, leaving no pleasant aftertaste.

uneven_extraction.question: Does the coffee taste like a confusing mix of both sour and bitter notes?
uneven_extraction.solution: This points to an uneven extraction. Check your grinder for consistency (burr grinders are best) and focus on an even pouring technique to saturate all grounds equally.

water_chemistry.question: Are you using very soft or distilled water?
water_chemistry.solution: Coffee needs some mineral content in the water to extract flavor properly. Try using filtered tap water or a specific brewing water solution.

salty.description: A distinct and unpleasant salty or savory taste. This is an uncommon but clear problem, often related to water.

water_softener.question: Do you use a household water softener that uses sodium ion exchange?
water_softener.solution: Do not use sodium-softened water for brewing coffee. Switch to using filtered or bottled water.

overextraction_dark_roast.question: Are you brewing a very dark, oily roast and also getting some bitter notes?
overextraction_dark_roast.solution: Sometimes, extreme over-extraction of very dark roasts can be perceived as salty. Try coarsening your grind slightly or reducing the brew time.

muddy.description: The coffee tastes unclear, heavy, and has an unpleasant gritty or dusty texture. The individual tasting notes are hard to distinguish.

too_many_fines.question: Do you see a lot of sediment or sludge at the bottom of your cup?
too_many_fines.solution: This is caused by 'fines' - tiny coffee particles. A higher quality burr grinder will produce a more consistent grind. Alternatively, you can try sifting the grounds.

filter_issue.question: Are you using a French Press or a metal filter? Or a very thin paper filter?
filter_issue.solution: Metal filters inherently allow more fine particles through. For a cleaner cup, try a high-quality paper filter. If using a French Press, press the plunger slowly and avoid pouring out the very last bit from the bottom.

stale.description: The coffee lacks any vibrant aroma or flavor. It tastes flat, lifeless, and generic, with a cardboard-like quality.

old_beans.question: Were your coffee beans roasted more than a month ago?
old_beans.solution: Coffee is best used within a few weeks of its roast date. Always buy freshly roasted beans and check for a 'roasted on' date on the bag.

pre_ground_coffee.question: Did you use coffee that was ground a long time ago (e.g., pre-ground from a store)?
pre_ground_coffee.solution: Coffee loses its aroma and flavor very quickly after grinding. For the best taste, grind your beans immediately before you brew.

improper_storage.question: Are you storing your coffee beans in an airtight container away from light, heat, and moisture?
improper_storage.solution: Store your whole beans in an opaque, airtight container in a cool, dark place. Avoid the refrigerator or freezer, as this can introduce moisture.

papery.description: A distinct, distracting flavor reminiscent of wet paper, cardboard, or wood, which masks the coffee's natural notes.

unrinsed_filter.question: Did you rinse your paper filter with hot water before adding the coffee grounds?
unrinsed_filter.solution: Always thoroughly rinse your paper filter with hot water before brewing. This washes away paper residue and preheats your brewer, making a significant difference.

low_quality_filter.question: Are you using a generic or very thin paper filter?
low_quality_filter.solution: Not all filters are created equal. Try a different brand of paper filter, as some impart more flavor than others. Oxygen-bleached filters generally impart less flavor.

metallic.description: A sharp, unpleasant metallic tang, like licking a coin, that can linger on the palate.

water_source.question: Are you brewing with hard water or water that has a high mineral content?
water_source.solution: Water with high mineral content, especially iron, can create a metallic taste. Try brewing with filtered or bottled water to see if the problem persists.

dirty_equipment.question: When was the last time you deep-cleaned your brewer, grinder, or kettle?
dirty_equipment.solution: Coffee oils can build up and go rancid, and mineral scale can accumulate in your kettle. Regularly clean and descale all your coffee equipment.

equipment_material.question: Is any part of your brewing equipment made of a low-quality metal that could be corroding?
equipment_material.solution: Ensure your equipment, especially metal parts in contact with hot water, is made of high-quality stainless steel and is free from rust or corrosion.
